page.title: 04Ecology Grove in Spring
page.content: Winter lapwings with their northern visitors the golden plovers have gone from the fields. First chiff-chaff and willow warblers are heard. Snow-white flowers of blackthorn bloom, later to give sloes for wine. Swallows and martins begin to arrive and we hear the first cuckoo. Hedgehogs snuffle about in gardens, bats hihernate no more. Chaucer's pet flower, the daisy, pops up on lawns and the cuckoo plant unfurls its leaves in hedgerows. The first butterfly, a yellow brimstone, flutters by. The last migrants arrive, the swifts, screaming joyfully across the skies, and the spotted flycatcher, choosing its perch from which it sallies back and forth for insects. At last the hawthorn smothers the hedgerows with sweet-smelling blooms. A chorus of birds fills the air at dawn and spring has arrived.
